newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai stocks soar, baht dives on currency float.
newsitem.headline: Thai stocks soar, baht dives on currency float.

text.p: Thai equity investors gave a hearty thumbs up to Thailand's move to float the beleaguered baht on Wednesday, pushing the battered bourse up nearly eight percent in busy dealings.
"The market sure likes it," said one foreign analyst.
The baht plunged to a record low against the dollar after the government announced that the currency would be floated in order to end uncertainty over Thailand's exchange rate policy.
Equity analysts and traders said the surprise, de facto devaluation was sorely needed to boost the stock market, which has recently slumped to eight-year lows.
The Stock Exchange of Thailand ended up 7.87 percent, or 40.93 points, at 568.21 on turnover of 10.4 billion baht.

The flotation effectively devalued the baht by 15-20 percent in offshore markets as the central bank dropped its pegged rate system against a basket of currencies and allowed market forces to determine the rate.

Foreign exchange were mainly on the sidelines as they waited for Bank of Thailand to set the new baht reference against the U.S. dollar. The central bank plans to publish a baht/dollar reference rate each day based on the baht's trading average.

The baht was quoted in offshore markets late on Wednesday at a rate of 28.80/29.60 following the early morning announcement by the central bank. In the domestic market it was at 27.50/28.50 to the dollar.
But stock market investors were upbeat.
Trade was dominated by foreign institutions as many local investors chose to remain on the sidelines until a clearer picture of Wednesday's currency changes emerged, analysts said.

"There was a tremendous buildup of funds that were waiting to go into the market if there was a devaluation or, as it happened, a flotation," George Morgan, country manager for ABN Amro Hoare Govett, told Reuters Financial Television.
Another analyst said many investors had been waiting to buy because Thai stocks were selling at very attractive prices.
"We were waiting for this (the flotation)," he said. "It was needed to asure investors."
Many stocks in the traditionally strong bank sector rose their 10 percent limit. On the foreign board, where there are no trading limits, some jumped more than 100 percent.
One analyst said the sharp jump in foreign prices may represent an over-reaction, and said there would likely be some rejigging following the initial knee-jerk reaction.
Richard Henderson, head of research at Krungthai Thanakit Plc, said the market gains would likely continue.
"I think it's the beginning rather than the end," he said.

The flotation is the latest in a series of surprise but decisive measures by authorities to try to boost markets and the economy, which is suffering its worst slump in more than a decade amid slowing growth, sharply lower exports and a troubled finance sector.
The latest move also impacted regional stock and money markets, and several governments reacted quickly to avoid any harmful ripple effect.
The Philippines sold hundreds of millions of dollars and forced up interest rates to shield its currency.
Manila stocks fell to close nearly two percent lower on Wednesday as wild swings in the foreign exchange market scared stock market investors.
For the first time in years, Bank Negara Malaysia used its own name to intervene in the foreign exchange market as it sold dollars early on Wednesday, dealers said.
The actual amount of dollars sold was thought to be small and more of a token resistance by the bank.
